content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students are given two small charged plastic disks that are on an air table, as shown. The disks are identical, have known mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, and have the same net charge. There is negligible friction between the disks and the table. The students are asked to use a straight-line graph to estimate the charge of one of the disks. The students have access to a meterstick and a motion sensor that can measure velocity and acceleration.

(a) Design a procedure for collecting data that would allow the students to estimate the charge of one of the disks with a straight-line graph. Provide enough detail so that students could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students are given two small charged plastic disks that are on an air table, as shown. The disks are identical, have known mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, and have the same net charge. There is negligible friction between the disks and the table. The students are asked to use a straight-line graph to estimate the charge of one of the disks. The students have access to a meterstick and a motion sensor that can measure velocity and acceleration.

(a) Design a procedure for collecting data that would allow the students to estimate the charge of one of the disks with a straight-line graph. Provide enough detail so that students could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.
(b) Describe how the data could be analyzed to estimate the charge of one of the disks.

In a second experiment, the students are asked to experimentally verify the value of the Coulomb constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>. The students place small, charged nonconducting Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> on a scale (which is then zeroed), as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> has net charge <math alttext="150 nano Coulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>150</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nC</mtext></math>. Other charged nonconducting spheres with known charges are brought near Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> so that the distance between the centers of the spheres is <math alttext="0.10 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.10</mtext><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math>. The scale reading is recorded for each charged sphere. The data are shown in the table.
Scale Reading <math alttext="in milli Newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>mN</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>Charge on Sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> <math alttext="in nano Coulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>nC</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="20.3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>20.3</mtext></math><math alttext="150" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>150</mtext></math><math alttext="10.3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>10.3</mtext></math><math alttext="75" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>75</mtext></math><math alttext="5.13" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>5.13</mtext></math><math alttext="38" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>38</mtext></math><math alttext="2.43" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>2.43</mtext></math><math alttext="19" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>19</mtext></math><math alttext="1.27" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>1.27</mtext></math><math alttext="9.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>9.4</mtext></math>
(c)

i. Indicate what measured and/or calculated quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value of the Coulomb constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided.

Vertical Axis:__________ Horizontal Axis:__________
ii. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) on the graph provided. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units, as appropriate.
iii. Draw the best-fit line for the data graphed in part (c)(ii).
(d) Using the best-fit line, calculate an experimental value of the Coulomb constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
